channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [HBASE-20070] website generation is failing
item.description:
website generation has been failing since Feb 20th

Checking out files: 100% (68971/68971), done.
Usage: grep [OPTION]... PATTERN [FILE]...
Try 'grep --help' for more information.
PUSHED is 2
 is not yet mentioned in the hbase-site commit log. Assuming we don't have it yet. 2
Building HBase
Java HotSpot(TM) 64-Bit Server VM warning: ignoring option MaxPermSize=256m; support was removed in 8.0
Java HotSpot(TM) 64-Bit Server VM warning: ignoring option MaxPermSize=256m; support was removed in 8.0
Failure: mvn clean site
Build step 'Execute shell' marked build as failure

The status email says

Build status: Still Failing

The HBase website has not been updated to incorporate HBase commit ${CURRENT_HBASE_COMMIT}.

Looking at the code where that grep happens, it looks like the env variable CURRENT_HBASE_COMMIT isn't getting set. That comes from some git command. I'm guessing the version of git changed on the build hosts and upended our assumptions.

we should fix this to 1) rely on git's porcelain interface, and 2) fail as soon as that git command fails

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
the git porcelain command for "tell me the full commit hash for the current working directory and error out if something goes wrong" is git rev-parse --verify HEAD.

alternatively we could expressly make this git rev-parse --verify origin/master if we wanted to guard against there being a local commit, or git rev-parse --verify origin/HEAD if we wanted to future proof against us deciding that our "place new stuff and docs lands first" should be something other than master.

getting the current commit hash has bean failing since August, but it seems it was failing in a way that still updated the website.

patch shortly.
correction to my original description, we should be using git plumbing commands, not porcelain. plumbing are the ones for scripts that don't change often.
I'm taking a look now.
let me post my WIP patch while the build runs locally then.
I get to the point of building the site and then it fails. attaching the log. I think it's unrelated to this git problem, so should have a new JIRA, WDYT misty?

-1

  • fixes a missing set of quotes that got flagged by shellcheck
I'll look at your patch if you look at mine.

I'll look at your patch if you look at mine.

sure.

Things still relying on git porcelain commands: clone, commit, push. I don't know how to do those via plumbing and couldn't figure it out with ~5 minutes of checking. so I'd like to leave it as follow-on work.
I don't think you can do absolutely everything with plumbing commands. Not 100% sure though.
I think that build failure is unrelated and probably a `git bisect` is needed to see who broke it.

Read through the HBASE-20070.misty.patch and it looks pretty similar to what I already have posted. It's still ignoring when commands fail unless they're expressly checked for, which I'd really like to avoid.

+PUSHED=$(git log -pretty=%H | grep ${CURRENT_HBASE_COMMIT})

this is still relying on the format string and then matching output when all we need to know is if a commit exists. why go through the extra work?

I think that build failure is unrelated and probably a `git bisect` is needed to see who broke it.

Okay, let me make a different jira for that. Should a passing mvn site be a blocker for this change to the jenkins script?
oh wait! it might just be because my local jdk defaults to jdk9. let me confirm or deny that.
Attached another version of mine with a couple fixes I noticed in testing.

Attached another version of mine with a couple fixes I noticed in testing.

I'm trying to incorporate things before uploading my current patch. could you summarize the difference from your previous patch? I'm not seeing it. (downloading the first one again now to diff)

#Remove previously-generated files
FILES_TO_REMOVE=("hbase-*"
                 "apidocs"
                 "devapidocs"
                 "testapidocs"
                 "testdevapidocs"
                 "xref"
                 "xref-test"
                 "*book*"
                 "*.html"
                 "*.pdf*"
                 "css"
                 "js"
                 "images")

for FILE in "${FILES_TO_REMOVE[@]}"; do
  if [ -e "${FILE}" ]; then
    echo "Removing ${WORKSPACE}/hbase-site/$FILE"
    rm -Rf "${FILE}"
  fi
done

Do you think this stanza is actually needed? Don't we delete the hbase-site directory and do a fresh clone on each run?

> index 06d160a64c..4628697c5f 100644
36c40
< +if [ -z "$CURRENT_HBASE_COMMIT "]; then
---
> +if [ -z "$CURRENT_HBASE_COMMIT" ]; then
55c59
< +PUSHED=$(git log -pretty=%H | grep ${CURRENT_HBASE_COMMIT})
---
> +PUSHED=$(git log --pretty=%H | grep ${CURRENT_HBASE_COMMIT})
Yeah it is still needed because that is stuff that is actually checked in but we want to nuke and pave it.

-2

  • added docs on assumptions based on chatting with Misty
  • avoids messing with JAVA_HOME and MAVEN_HOME if they exist

The way the script tried to set JAVA_HOME was effectively unsetting it on my machine, which meant I got jdk9 which didn't work.

still getting an error on running site, it looks like from trying to make javadocs.
maybe the site failure is HBASE-15753?

A little bit of feedback on your patches so far. Some of this may be me not understanding certain ways of doing things in Bash, so forgive me if so.

 

if [ "${PUSHED}" -ne 0 ]; then
echo "$CURRENT_HBASE_COMMIT is already mentioned in the hbase-site commit log. Not building."
exit 0
else

I think this might not be quite right (mine was also probably wrong). If I am understanding this correctly, this will pass if the hash is in any branch we know about, not just `master`, but I think we only care if it is in `master`. Can we narrow it down more? I'm also not in love with this indent-less syntax for the if contents.

 

I think we need to document that the stuff that removes ~/.m2 may not work locally but that's specifically to try to avoid Jenkins server problems so it can probably be ignored locally. In fact maybe there is some cleverer way for us to sandbox ourselves, but I am not a Maven expert.

 

I think maybe we need to add a –push=true or similar flag to this script so we can do local tests without it always pushing the new site.

I think this might not be quite right (mine was also probably wrong). If I am understanding this correctly, this will pass if the hash is in any branch we know about, not just `master`, but I think we only care if it is in `master`. Can we narrow it down more? I'm also not in love with this indent-less syntax for the if contents.

the git command that counted things for PUSHED only traces back commits starting from some reference (in this case the local HEAD), so it should only count things in the asf-site branch of the hbase-site repo. Which I think is correct?

The if block in my patch should be indented two spaces. It is when I open things in vim at least.

I think we need to document that the stuff that removes ~/.m2 may not work locally but that's specifically to try to avoid Jenkins server problems so it can probably be ignored locally. In fact maybe there is some cleverer way for us to sandbox ourselves, but I am not a Maven expert.

If WORKSPACE exists, then the temp directory should work. We could move it out of this script though, and just have folks pass in a path for what they want used for the maven local repository. we could then manage the per-workspace repository via jenkins. better?

I think maybe we need to add a –push=true or similar flag to this script so we can do local tests without it always pushing the new site.

Sure. I've been commenting out the push while I have a WIP. I can add a flag for publishing.
I think maybe we aren't supposed to be doing mvn clean site after doing the install? Maybe just mvn site. This might be the cause of the Javadoc errors you're seeing. I'm testing locally now.

I'm confused why the Javadoc is failing even with this in the POM:

 

<configuration>
<!-- TODO HBASE-15041 clean up our javadocs so jdk8 linter can be used -->
<additionalparam>-Xdoclint:none</additionalparam>
</configuration>

I found that referred to at http://www.locked.de/2015/04/05/how-to-ignore-maven-javadoc-errors-in-java-8/.

 

But I think that maybe the configuration clause is actually in the wrong place in the POM. I'm testing this assumption now.

No, adding the configuration to the reportsets in the POM didn't help either. :/ I am confused, but need to step away from this for a bit. I'll attach my patch as it currently stands, for your review. I didn't try to normalize to your patch yet, so ignore any changes you incorporated already.

-3

  • starts forcing -e instead of relying on how the script is called
  • adds command line arg parsing, including optional working directory, local repo, and publishing
  • creates a working directory in /tmp if one isn't given
  • adds an explicit error message if we get a blank "current hash" for the hbase repo

Note that invoking the script is totally different now:

 bash hbase/dev-support/jenkins-scripts/generate-hbase-website.sh --help
Usage: hbase/dev-support/jenkins-scripts/generate-hbase-website.sh [options] /path/to/hbase/checkout

    --working-dir /path/to/use  Path for writing logs and a local checkout of hbase-site repo.
                                if given must exist.
                                defaults to making a directory in /tmp.
    --local-repo /path/for/maven/.m2  Path for putting local maven repo.
                                if given must exist.
                                defaults to making a clean directory in --working-dir.
    --publish                   if given, will attempt to push results back to the hbase-site repo.
    --help                      show this usage message.

Also note that even if you pass in the --publish flag, the actual push to git is still commented out.

I figured it out!

HBASE-20032 changed it so that we're using maven-javadoc-plugin version 3.0.0 for reports, which is when the actual site goal started failing on jenkins. prior to that, wether mvnsite worked or not would depend on the maven version you had, since we weren't specifying a version for the maven-javadoc-plugin in the reports section. version 3.0.0 of the javadoc plugin removed the configuration value we use to turn off the javadoc linter in MJAVADOC-474. They added the ability to directly configure the doclint setting via MJAVADOC-387 and made a new way to give custom javadoc parameters in MJAVADOC-475. Unfortunately, nothing in the maven output makes this obvious.

Everything not in the site generation is still working because in all those cases we're still using maven-javadoc-plugin version 2.10.3.

ugh. what a mess.

I'll get a new patch that a) updates our use of maven-javadoc-plugin to match in non-report contexts, b) consistently disables the linter.
Also, MJAVADOC-511 is interesting as a way we might have been spared some pain here.

-4

  • make the version of maven-javadoc-plugin consistently 3.0.0 and update how we turn off the javadoc linter.

After this addition I still get a failure, but now it's a weird dependency resolution thing instead of a javadoc complaint.
I probably won't have time to keep digging on this today. I'll pick it back up again later this week.

-1 on patch 4, because it won't run on Mac out of the box, due to differences in the cp command. I solved a similar thing with sed here: https://github.com/docker/docker.github.io/blob/master/_scripts/fetch-upstream-resources.sh#L10

 

However it looks like Linux honors the -r flag for cp now, so maybe you can just switch the -au to -r everywhere (after verifying on a Jenkins worker that it has a version of cp that supports the flag?)

 

I've changed the cp locally and will do more testing today.

 

(I sent this hours ago but it didn't post because the session was expired but the page doesn't have the smarts to realize that.)
curious. I'm using a mac locally, so I wonder why this didn't fail for me.

Just to confirm, this is the line I'm updating, right?

cp -au "${component_dir}"/target/staging/* .

You might be using cp from Homebrew. If it is in /usr/local/bin that's probably what's going on. Yes, that's the line. I'm pretty sure that Linux cp supporting -r is new so it is possible Jenkins won't work with this, in which case you'll have to somehow check what flags are supported or just use mv or something (even rsync but that's more complicated).
FYI with that one change, I got a totally clean run of all phases including adding the files, generating the patch, etc. I can't reproduce the dependency problem you were seeing.
Testing latest patch now.

-5

  • update use of cp to use flags that also work on mac.

I updated cp to use -pPR, which should be "recursively copy everything while maintaining file metadata (owner, timestamp, access)" on both Mac (10.11.6 built-in tested) and Linux (CentOS 7.4 tested).
+1 on version 5.

Actually soft -1 on version 5. I forgot to mention that there is something about the way you are adding files to git that is making it interactive (you have to press q to get out of a pager). I didn't look into it to see what the deal is but probably not appropriate for a Jenkins job.

-1 overall

what's your maven and git versions?

I found the cause of my error and maybe the extra long site build times that stack has been complaining about for some time.

for the site goal we're rebuilding the whole project several times over because only some modules disable the site plugin and those that don't are inheriting the top level reports.

 

I'm working on a fix now. If folks prefer I'm happy to push v5 and continue my fixing in another jira.
oh found it! it's the git diff.

-6

  - make the git diff skip the use of a pager by teeing to a log file
  - avoid duplicative site executions (each of which causes a 4x duplicate of building the project), mostly by relying on skipping in hbase-build-configuration
  - correct the name of log files to reflect that we're installing locally and then running site (rather than 'build' and 'install')
  - skip the enforcer plugin all the time, we don't need to repeat that in the website build
  - skip the compiler plugin in our site invocation, since we just installed everything we don't need the forked javadoc compile to build stuff.

 

looks like this set of changes also gets through the website generation in something like half or maybe even a third of the time?

-1 overall

+1 on commit to branch-2 now. Need it to make rc iiuc. Thanks.

TestProcedurePriority has failed a few times. Has nought to do w/ site generation.

Maybe I don't need to wait on this patch for beta-2 afterall... will see.

Looking at patch...

avoid duplicative site executions (each of which causes a 4x duplicate of building the project), mostly by relying on skipping in hbase-build-configuration

How does this mechanism work? Why we have to set snippet in hbase-annotations/pom.xml and hbase-shaded-check-invariants/pom.xml ?

Nice usage function.

<doclint>none</doclint> in general properties gets picked up by javadoc? Thats good.

This was just noise?

168 #echo "Dumping current environment:"
169 #env

...and this unnecessary work?

160 git fetch origin
161 git reset --hard origin/asf-site

Is this meant to be commented out?

275 #if git push origin asf-site; then

Patch looks great.

avoid duplicative site executions (each of which causes a 4x duplicate of building the project), mostly by relying on skipping in hbase-build-configuration

How does this mechanism work? Why we have to set snippet in hbase-annotations/pom.xml and hbase-shaded-check-invariants/pom.xml ?

Some of the modules don't have hbase-build-configuration as a parent pom, so they don't inherit the skip flag for maven site. IIRC, hbase-annotations doesn't have it as a parent so that we can reference that module within the hbase-build-configuration configs. hbase-shaded-check-invariants maybe doesn't because it doesn't involve building any code?

Nice usage function.

thanks!

<doclint>none</doclint> in general properties gets picked up by javadoc? Thats good.

yep. There was some talk in the maven-javadoc-plugin community about making the name better scoped, i.e. maven.javadoc.doclint, but AFAICT that change never happened. I really like that this property gets picked up both in the normal lifecycle (javadoc:javadoc) and in the site reporting section.

This was just noise?

168 #echo "Dumping current environment:"
169 #env

Since it was commented out I figured best to just remove it. I can add it back if you prefer. We should really have the job use the "gather machine stats" script if we want that kind of info though.

...and this unnecessary work?

160 git fetch origin
161 git reset --hard origin/asf-site

yeah, we were doing it at the end but we do a fresh clone every run.

Is this meant to be commented out?

275 #if git push origin asf-site; then

That's been commented out to ensure I don't push to the remote. I'll make it not commented out before pushing. I can update the patch with that change in place if folks prefer.

-7 feedback from github pr

  • add debug notes when we're using a default cli option
  • remove duplicative code comment
  • remove outdated jdk option that isn't needed in jdk8+
  • make it so --publish actually will push to the remote repo
(the github PR is also up to date with v7 here)

-7 LGTM with code review (on Github) but I haven’t been able to test this locally. It would be nice if someone did a test run before foisting this on Jenkins. Remember the Jenkins job needs to be updated to run the script with the new syntax too.

I'm +1.

This will fix my current problem cutting an RC? I can't make the RC w/o doing below revert and my sense is that this will fix it (Takes a while to verify).

commit b34f8f959ff5dc3d301128768dc5bf3e87205390
Author: Michael Stack <stack@duboce.net>
Date: Thu Mar 1 23:49:09 2018 -0800

Revert "HBASE-20032 Receving multiple warnings for missing reporting.plugins.plugin.version"

This reverts commit c5ca3c2fe6bdf25ef54f68e48d2d3629c06f37f7.
What you see as benefits dev'ing against github making PRs busbey? Thanks. You like going this route?

pushed to master and branch-2.

updating the website jenkins job now.

stack, I put the github PR up because it's misty's preference and she's been doing most of the review here.

Can you give me the command that fails for you on branch-2? I can test it out locally and see if there's an easy fix. what maven version are you using?
looking at the diff from HBASE-20032, I believe this patch will fix the issue you're having stack. I suspect you're getting the same error I was getting in my tests.

git version 2.7.4
fatal: 'refs/remotes/origin/HEAD' - not a valid ref

Ugh. such an old version. I'll mess around with teh job later and get this to work.

I'm on it busbey I've started a new build that includes your push. Thanks. Will report back.

I was running make_rc.sh. Thats how I found the problem.

FAILURE: Integrated in Jenkins build HBase-Trunk_matrix #4677 (See https://builds.apache.org/job/HBase-Trunk_matrix/4677/)
